content: Okay, I need some encouragement here. I love the Army and I love being a leader, especially when I was in Iraq. Joining was the best decision I've ever made in my life. But I've been having doubts as to whether or not I should continue to serve. Here's the scenario as briefly as I can state it: I joined, like most of us, out of a love of our country and our Constitution. I take the whole "support and defend the Constitution of the United States of America" very seriously. One of the things I admire about our Constitution and the legal system that arises from it is the involuntary universality of its rights and restrictions. Boumediene v. Bush found that enemy combatants have the same rights to trial in the federal court system and habeas corpus as the President, and Hamdan v. Rumsfeld found that the President has no more power to circumvent the law as an enemy combatant. I treasure that equality and fairness granted by the Constitution. I am, however, starting to feel like I am in the vast, vast minority. Two consecutive Executive offices have tried to violate both of these rulings and no one seems to care that much. Is there a point to supporting and defending the Constitution if no one else is willing? Or is it moot because I'm just imagining that I'm the only one who is concerned? (just to cut off some ad hominem attacks: I'm actually a Republican, and if I ever agree with the ACLU it's only because they're accidentally right)

content: It's not up to an Army man to decide if a president violated law. Many men have fallen flat on their face trying to play lawyer & interpreting laws. Orders must be followed while others argue constitutionality. For those of us who've been around awhile, case laws change more often than I change my underwear. I don't pay much attention to them unless it comes down my chain-of-command.

content: I've participated in 3 seperate trials this year already. Lawyers argue over the color of pencils. It will take many more years before something complicated gets litigated. Anyone, particularly a soldier, who thinks they know these issues enough to make a calculated decision is playing with fire. We must stick to our own jobs.
